plants.name: Rudbeckia hirta
plants.description: A hardy perennial wildflower and garden plant known for its bright yellow petals and dark brown central cone. It attracts pollinators like bees and butterflies and is often used in naturalistic plantings and meadows.
plants.location: Native to eastern and central North America; commonly cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Black-eyed Susans are often used in roadside plantings because they tolerate drought and poor soils well.

plants.name: Campsis radicans
plants.description: A vigorous deciduous vine producing large, trumpet-shaped orange to red flowers that attract hummingbirds. It blooms profusely on mature growth in late summer to early autumn.
plants.location: Native to the southeastern United States, widely cultivated in warm temperate climates
plants.funFact: The trumpet-shaped flowers are specially adapted to attract hummingbirds as their primary pollinators.

plants.name: Dahlia pinnata
plants.description: A tuberous ornamental plant renowned for its striking, large, multi-petaled flowers in a wide range of colors. Blooms are abundant until the first frost, making dahlias a popular late-season garden favorite.
plants.location: Native to Mexico and Central America; widely cultivated globally in temperate regions
plants.funFact: Dahlias were named after the 18th-century Swedish botanist Anders Dahl and were once the national flower of Mexico.

plants.name: Heuchera americana
plants.description: A native perennial wildflower with small bell-shaped flowers borne on tall stems above attractive, often colorful foliage. It blooms in late summer to early fall and is valued in shade gardens.
plants.location: Eastern United States, especially rocky woodlands and slopes
plants.funFact: Heuchera species are commonly called alumroot because their roots were historically used as an astringent.
